elements.content: Lanthanide-based metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) and coordination polymers (CPs) attract much attention as candidates for optical ratiometric thermometry applications. Thus far, excitation of these materials was mainly performed in the ultraviolet that drastically limits their applicability as sensors, e.g., in tissue biological thermometry. As a remedy for this constraint, for the first time, we leverage a nonlinear optical process, the three-photon absorption property of Eu,Tb-CPs to shift the excitation wavelength from ultraviolet into near-infrared region. Experiments demonstrate that three-photon induced thermometric responses of Eu,Tb-CPs follow excellent optical characteristics similar to those determined for one-photon excitation, yet are not identical. The relative sensitivity reaches a very high value of 2.91%K–1 in the physiological temperature region. We put forward a notion that utilizing multiphoton absorption is a general strategy for realizing NIR-to-VIS remote temperature sensing in practically any CP that is designed for UV-to-VIS thermometry.
elements.clean_text: Lanthanide-based metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and coordination polymers (CPs) attract much attention as candidates for optical ratiometric thermometry applications. Thus far, excitation of these materials was mainly performed in the ultraviolet that drastically limits their applicability as sensors, e.g., in tissue biological thermometry. As a remedy for this constraint, for the first time, we leverage a nonlinear optical process, the three-photon absorption property of Eu,Tb-CPs to shift the excitation wavelength from ultraviolet into near-infrared region. Experiments demonstrate that three-photon induced thermometric responses of Eu,Tb-CPs follow excellent optical characteristics similar to those determined for one-photon excitation, yet are not identical. The relative sensitivity reaches a very high value of 2.91%K-1 in the physiological temperature region. We put forward a notion that utilizing multiphoton absorption is a general strategy for realizing NIR-to-VIS remote temperature sensing in practically any CP that is designed for UV-to-VIS thermometry.

elements.content: The simultaneous absorption by a material of two or more photons is referred to as multiphoton absorption (MPA). As a nonlinear optical process, the MPA is characterized by two unique features: (i) the instantaneous absorption of several photons of low energy can populate an excited state that normally may or may not (depending on symmetry constraints) be reachable by absorption of one high energy photon, which in practice allows one to use near-infrared (NIR) photons to excite bands in the ultraviolet and visible regions, under sufficiently intense laser illumination; (ii) the absorption probability is a superlinear function of the excitation radiance, which offers a significant advantage over one-photon (linear) absorption by exciting the material only within the focal region. Both these phenomena made possible advanced applications such as multiphoton fluorescent microimaging, 3D patterning, and optical data storage.
elements.clean_text: The simultaneous absorption by a material of two or more photons is referred to as multiphoton absorption (MPA). As a nonlinear optical process, the MPA is characterized by two unique features: (i) the instantaneous absorption of several photons of low energy can populate an excited state that normally may or may not (depending on symmetry constraints) be reachable by absorption of one high energy photon, which in practice allows one to use near-infrared (NIR) photons to excite bands in the ultraviolet and visible regions, under sufficiently intense laser illumination; (ii) the absorption probability is a superlinear function of the excitation radiance, which offers a significant advantage over one-photon (linear) absorption by exciting the material only within the focal region. Both these phenomena made possible advanced applications such as multiphoton fluorescent microimaging, 3D patterning, and optical data storage.

elements.content: The fabrication of MPA-active materials for photonic applications raises the all-important question of how their NLO response can be maximized. Numerous successful molecular design principles have been established for a range of molecular materials including organic dyes, metal complexes and dendrimers, as based on exhaustive structure–property studies conducted since early 90s. Only in recent years has it emerged that polymeric multidimensional materials, coordination polymers (CPs), and the CP subclass metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) can offer competitively high MPA cross-sections, with additional distinctive features not available for discrete, molecular species. Those features include synthetic control of their fine structure in 3D, the possibility to embed guest molecules into pores to alter their photophysical properties, the access to various architectures through the molecular block approach, etc. Nevertheless, the actual origin of high MPA cross sections of MOFs remains rather enigmatic and this is why recent studies revolve around the determination of factors that are responsible for the observed high optical nonlinearities. It was found that aggregation-related effects such as conformational strain and rigidification of framework, provide a unique means toward varying the strength of MOF’s NLO response. Worth noting is that the sizable MPA of MOFs in the NIR region has enabled two useful NLO applications of MOFs so far: the two-photon patterning of MOF-based photoresists and the multiphoton pumped lasing.
elements.clean_text: The fabrication of MPA-active materials for photonic applications raises the all-important question of how their NLO response can be maximized. Numerous successful molecular design principles have been established for a range of molecular materials including organic dyes, metal complexes and dendrimers, as based on exhaustive structure-property studies conducted since early 90s. Only in recent years has it emerged that polymeric multidimensional materials, coordination polymers (CPs), and the CP subclass metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) can offer competitively high MPA cross-sections, with additional distinctive features not available for discrete, molecular species. Those features include synthetic control of their fine structure in 3D, the possibility to embed guest molecules into pores to alter their photophysical properties, the access to various architectures through the molecular block approach, etc. Nevertheless, the actual origin of high MPA cross sections of MOFs remains rather enigmatic and this is why recent studies revolve around the determination of factors that are responsible for the observed high optical nonlinearities. It was found that aggregation-related effects such as conformational strain and rigidification of framework, provide a unique means toward varying the strength of MOF's NLO response. Worth noting is that the sizable MPA of MOFs in the NIR region has enabled two useful NLO applications of MOFs so far: the two-photon patterning of MOF-based photoresists and the multiphoton pumped lasing.

elements.content: In the field of luminescent sensing, including thermometry, there is a strong trend to impart lanthanide-centered up-conversion property onto luminophores so that excitation and emission bands are located in red to infrared region, within so-called “windows of biological transparency.” Two main phenomena are currently employed to realize the photon up-conversion: excited state absorption of selected lanthanides such as Er3+, Tm3+, and Ho3+ and energy transfer from Yb3+ to the above ions. Despite a relatively narrow selection of available excitation wavelengths, these processes proved to be extremely useful tools for construction of up-converting inorganic nanomaterials for biological applications. Unfortunately, the lanthanide-centered upconversion in CPs presents a major challenge because multiphonon relaxation processes of the metal–organic skeleton effectively curb the overall efficiency of photon up-conversion phenomena. In view of these limiting factors, CP-based thermometry needs to find an alternative strategy for obtaining NIR-excitable temperature sensors, using photon management mechanisms different from the already utilized rare earth-centered up-conversion.
elements.clean_text: In the field of luminescent sensing, including thermometry, there is a strong trend to impart lanthanide-centered up-conversion property onto luminophores so that excitation and emission bands are located in red to infrared region, within so-called "windows of biological transparency." Two main phenomena are currently employed to realize the photon up-conversion: excited state absorption of selected lanthanides such as Er3+, Tm3+, and Ho3+ and energy transfer from Yb3+ to the above ions. Despite a relatively narrow selection of available excitation wavelengths, these processes proved to be extremely useful tools for construction of up-converting inorganic nanomaterials for biological applications. Unfortunately, the lanthanide-centered upconversion in CPs presents a major challenge because multiphonon relaxation processes of the metal-organic skeleton effectively curb the overall efficiency of photon up-conversion phenomena. In view of these limiting factors, CP-based thermometry needs to find an alternative strategy for obtaining NIR-excitable temperature sensors, using photon management mechanisms different from the already utilized rare earth-centered up-conversion.

elements.content: MPA processes appear to be a well-tailored solution here, because of their ability to reach high energy states with the use of long-wavelength laser sources. To the best of our knowledge, the only example of NLO temperature sensing was demonstrated by Wang et al. in nanohybrids of fluorene-based conjugated polymer with Eu3+-1,3-dione complex. In their material, the organic polymer performed as a two-photon absorbing antenna for 720 nm fs exciting radiation, whereas the Eu3+ complex served as an energy acceptor and as emission center of temperature-dependent luminescence. No similar approach has been applied, however, to MOFs and CPs thus far.
elements.clean_text: MPA processes appear to be a well-tailored solution here, because of their ability to reach high energy states with the use of long-wavelength laser sources. To the best of our knowledge, the only example of NLO temperature sensing was demonstrated by Wang et al. in nanohybrids of fluorene-based conjugated polymer with Eu3+-1,3-dione complex. In their material, the organic polymer performed as a two-photon absorbing antenna for 720 nm fs exciting radiation, whereas the Eu3+ complex served as an energy acceptor and as emission center of temperature-dependent luminescence. No similar approach has been applied, however, to MOFs and CPs thus far.

elements.content: Accordingly, in this contribution, we propose to leverage the MPA process in the NIR region in order to excite UV electronic transitions of ligands building up CPs so that the harvested energy can be converted into temperature-dependent lanthanide luminescence (a). Indeed, we specifically target UV transitions, since the great majority of extant CP-based thermometric studies takes advantage of excitation in the 260–400 nm region, as this is a reliable strategy to gain ligand-sensitized luminescence of the Eu3+/Tb3+ ratiometric pair, as well as of ligand fluorescence, which also can be used as a thermometric gauge. If the MPA-induced luminescence is strong enough to be used for reliable temperature determination, this approach should enable NIR-to-VIS thermometry in virtually any CP that possesses UV-to-VIS thermometric response. To demonstrate that this is indeed a feasible strategy, we have prepared and investigated two new ratiometric thermometers based on Eu, Tb codoped CPs, which are three-photon absorption active.
elements.clean_text: Accordingly, in this contribution, we propose to leverage the MPA process in the NIR region in order to excite UV electronic transitions of ligands building up CPs so that the harvested energy can be converted into temperature-dependent lanthanide luminescence (a). Indeed, we specifically target UV transitions, since the great majority of extant CP-based thermometric studies takes advantage of excitation in the 260-400 nm region, as this is a reliable strategy to gain ligand-sensitized luminescence of the Eu3+/Tb3+ ratiometric pair, as well as of ligand fluorescence, which also can be used as a thermometric gauge. If the MPA-induced luminescence is strong enough to be used for reliable temperature determination, this approach should enable NIR-to-VIS thermometry in virtually any CP that possesses UV-to-VIS thermometric response. To demonstrate that this is indeed a feasible strategy, we have prepared and investigated two new ratiometric thermometers based on Eu, Tb codoped CPs, which are three-photon absorption active.

elements.content: (a) Energy levels diagram highlighting the use of MPA excitation (specifically 3PA) for effecting the thermometric luminescent response of Eu,Tb-codoped CP. (b) Left: distorted six-nodal rings comprising three metal centers and three 1,3,5-btc ligands; Right: honeycomb-like metal–organic layer parallel to the ab plane. (c) Emission spectra of 1Eu23Tb obtained under one-photon conditions (λexc = 337 nm) measured in the 294–373 K range. (d) Plots of integral intensities of 5D0 → 7F2 of Eu3+ (red dots) and 5D4 → 7F5 of Tb3+ (black dots) f–f electronic transitions in the function of temperature. Insets contain photographs of luminescence colors at three temperatures (299, 336, and 373 K).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Energy levels diagram highlighting the use of MPA excitation (specifically 3PA) for effecting the thermometric luminescent response of Eu,Tb-codoped CP. (b) Left: distorted six-nodal rings comprising three metal centers and three 1,3,5-btc ligands; Right: honeycomb-like metal-organic layer parallel to the ab plane. (c) Emission spectra of 1Eu23Tb obtained under one-photon conditions (λexc = 337 nm) measured in the 294-373 K range. (d) Plots of integral intensities of 5D0 → 7F2 of Eu3+ (red dots) and 5D4 → 7F5 of Tb3+ (black dots) f-f electronic transitions in the function of temperature. Insets contain photographs of luminescence colors at three temperatures (299, 336, and 373 K).

elements.content: The reaction of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (1,3,5-btc), phenantroline (phen), and Gd­(NO3)3·6H2O at 90 °C in dimethylformamide (dmf) afforded colorless polyhedral crystals of composition Gd­(phen)­(1,3,5-btc)­(dmf)·dmf (100Gd), which were subjected to X-ray diffraction analysis. CP thermometers were obtained using the same synthetic conditions, but part of gadolinium nitrate was substituted by appropriate amounts of europium and terbium salts, to obtain crystals containing 0.88 mol % Eu, 22.87 mol % Tb (1Eu23Tb) and, 1.74 mol % Eu, 21.88 mol % Tb (2Eu22Tb) see the for details. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) evidenced the crystal phase of the doped samples to be identical with that of 100Gd and their bulk phase purity (). The isostructurality is also confirmed by IR and Raman spectroscopies (). All CPs are thermally stable to at least 150 °C, see .
elements.clean_text: The reaction of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid (1,3,5-btc), phenantroline (phen), and Gd(NO3)3⋅6H2O at 90 °C in dimethylformamide (dmf) afforded colorless polyhedral crystals of composition Gd(phen)(1,3,5-btc)(dmf)⋅dmf (100Gd), which were subjected to X-ray diffraction analysis. CP thermometers were obtained using the same synthetic conditions, but part of gadolinium nitrate was substituted by appropriate amounts of europium and terbium salts, to obtain crystals containing 0.88 mol % Eu, 22.87 mol % Tb (1Eu23Tb) and, 1.74 mol % Eu, 21.88 mol % Tb (2Eu22Tb) see the  for details. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) evidenced the crystal phase of the doped samples to be identical with that of 100Gd and their bulk phase purity (). The isostructurality is also confirmed by IR and Raman spectroscopies (). All CPs are thermally stable to at least 150 °C, see .

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that 100Gd crystallizes in the Pbca space group of the ortorhombic crystal system. There is one crystallographically independent Gd3+ ion, whose nine-coordinated coordination sphere comprises one phen molecule, three 1,3,5-btc molecules, each cooordinating through carboxylate groups in chelating μ–κO,O mode, and one dmf molecule. The geometry of Gd3+ coordination environment, according to the continuous shape measure (CShM) calculations, is best described as muffin polyhedron (point group C s , CShM value of 2.101). Three metal centers and three 1,3,5-btc ligands are connected into distorted six-nodal rings which further extend into a honeycomb-like layer parallel to the ab plane (b). The topological simplification of coordination net confirmed that 100Gd is a two-dimensional, three-connected net of the topological type hcb. Note that in the structure there is no water molecule embedded, which limits possible radiationless energy decays via O–H oscillators.
elements.clean_text: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction revealed that 100Gd crystallizes in the Pbca space group of the ortorhombic crystal system. There is one crystallographically independent Gd3+ ion, whose nine-coordinated coordination sphere comprises one phen molecule, three 1,3,5-btc molecules, each cooordinating through carboxylate groups in chelating μ-κO,O mode, and one dmf molecule. The geometry of Gd3+ coordination environment, according to the continuous shape measure (CShM) calculations, is best described as muffin polyhedron (point group C  s , CShM value of 2.101). Three metal centers and three 1,3,5-btc ligands are connected into distorted six-nodal rings which further extend into a honeycomb-like layer parallel to the ab plane (b). The topological simplification of coordination net confirmed that 100Gd is a two-dimensional, three-connected net of the topological type hcb. Note that in the structure there is no water molecule embedded, which limits possible radiationless energy decays via O-H oscillators.

elements.content: Before focusing on peculiarities of the NLO thermometry, we have explored fundamental thermometric properties of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb, using a nitrogen laser as a UV excitation source (337 nm). Here, the description of 1Eu23Tb properties is provided as a representative example. The temperature evolution of emission spectra (294–393 K) is presented in c, whereas the corresponding integral intensities of 5D4 → 7F5 (Tb3+) and 5D0 → 7F2 (Eu3+) transitions are plotted in d. Visually, the luminescence color transitioned from green, through yellow into dark orange upon heating in that range, as shown in inset photographs. Indeed, in quantitative terms, the integral intensity of the 5D4 → 7F5 transition experiences an abrupt drop of ca. 85% with the temperature increase, whereas the integral intensity of 5D0 → 7F2 follows a weakly rising trend. The temperature-dependent changes are also reflected in time-resolved luminescence characteristics: the lifetime of 5D4 → 7F5 transition decreases from 592 to 137 μs as the temperature is increased from 297 to 393 K (), whereas the decay lifetime of 5D0 → 7F2 transition displays a minor decrease in that temperature range (from 996 to 819 μs, see in the SI). Note that the time-resolved curves of 5D0 → 7F2 transition have a significant component of slow initial rise, calculated to be on the order of hundreds of microseconds (360 μs at 297 K), which suggests that the 5D0 level of Eu3+ is fed by nonradiative energy transfer (). The same features are observed for 2Eu22Tb (). Additionally, the Tb3+ to Eu3+ energy transfer is supported by room temperature excitation spectra of Tb3+ 5D4 → 7F5 and Eu3+ 5D0 → 7F2 transitions (). Although the excitation spectrum of 5D4 → 7F5 transition displays excitation bands typical for Tb3+ solely, the excitation spectrum of Eu3+ 5D0 → 7F2 features the characteristic bands of both Tb3+ and Eu3+, which confirms the presence of Tb3+ to Eu3+ energy transfer.
elements.clean_text: Before focusing on peculiarities of the NLO thermometry, we have explored fundamental thermometric properties of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb, using a nitrogen laser as a UV excitation source (337 nm). Here, the description of 1Eu23Tb properties is provided as a representative example. The temperature evolution of emission spectra (294-393 K) is presented in c, whereas the corresponding integral intensities of 5D4 → 7F5 (Tb3+) and 5D0 → 7F2 (Eu3+) transitions are plotted in d. Visually, the luminescence color transitioned from green, through yellow into dark orange upon heating in that range, as shown in inset photographs. Indeed, in quantitative terms, the integral intensity of the 5D4 → 7F5 transition experiences an abrupt drop of ca. 85% with the temperature increase, whereas the integral intensity of 5D0 → 7F2 follows a weakly rising trend. The temperature-dependent changes are also reflected in time-resolved luminescence characteristics: the lifetime of 5D4 → 7F5 transition decreases from 592 to 137 μs as the temperature is increased from 297 to 393 K (), whereas the decay lifetime of 5D0 → 7F2 transition displays a minor decrease in that temperature range (from 996 to 819 μs, see  in the SI). Note that the time-resolved curves of 5D0 → 7F2 transition have a significant component of slow initial rise, calculated to be on the order of hundreds of microseconds (360 μs at 297 K), which suggests that the 5D0 level of Eu3+ is fed by nonradiative energy transfer (). The same features are observed for 2Eu22Tb (). Additionally, the Tb3+ to Eu3+ energy transfer is supported by room temperature excitation spectra of Tb3+ 5D4 → 7F5 and Eu3+ 5D0 → 7F2 transitions (). Although the excitation spectrum of 5D4 → 7F5 transition displays excitation bands typical for Tb3+ solely, the excitation spectrum of Eu3+ 5D0 → 7F2 features the characteristic bands of both Tb3+ and Eu3+, which confirms the presence of Tb3+ to Eu3+ energy transfer.

elements.content: Room-temperature quantum yield (QY) measurements of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb microcrystalline powders (λexc = 330 nm) gave values of 17.3% and 10.5%, respectively. Lower QY of 2Eu22Tb vs 1Eu23Tb suggests that, in these systems, Eu3+ centers dissipate energy to a larger extent through nonradiative channels than Tb3+ ones, hence low Eu3+ concentrations are preferred for maximized emission brightness.
elements.clean_text: Room-temperature quantum yield (QY) measurements of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb microcrystalline powders (λexc = 330 nm) gave values of 17.3% and 10.5%, respectively. Lower QY of 2Eu22Tb vs 1Eu23Tb suggests that, in these systems, Eu3+ centers dissipate energy to a larger extent through nonradiative channels than Tb3+ ones, hence low Eu3+ concentrations are preferred for maximized emission brightness.

elements.content: A figure of merit commonly used for standardization of thermometers, the thermometric parameter Δ, is defined as the ratio of integral areas of 5D4 → 7F5 (Tb3+) to 5D0 → 7F2 (Eu3+) transitions. The thermal dependence of Δ, used as a basis for calibration curves, is well-described by a monoexponential function (a,b, black traces) for both 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb. Therefore, the presented here CP thermometers belong to the pattern I class, in line with the classification proposed by Rocha et al. wherein the exponential dependence of thermometric parameter is due to rapid decrease of intensity of one band, and approximately constant intensity of the second band. The relative sensitivity (S r), calculated as S r = |∂Δ/∂T|/Δ is a constant value equal to the exponent of the determined calibration curve. Thus, both 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb CPs feature in the 293–393 K region large Sr values of 2.37% K–1 and 2.71% K–1, respectively. To the best of our knowledge, those values of S r are among the highest determined for UV-excitable Eu, Tb-codoped ratiometric thermometers operating within the physiological region.
elements.clean_text: A figure of merit commonly used for standardization of thermometers, the thermometric parameter Δ, is defined as the ratio of integral areas of 5D4 → 7F5 (Tb3+) to 5D0 → 7F2 (Eu3+) transitions. The thermal dependence of Δ, used as a basis for calibration curves, is well-described by a monoexponential function (a,b, black traces) for both 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb. Therefore, the presented here CP thermometers belong to the pattern I class, in line with the classification proposed by Rocha et al. wherein the exponential dependence of thermometric parameter is due to rapid decrease of intensity of one band, and approximately constant intensity of the second band. The relative sensitivity (S r), calculated as S r = |∂Δ/∂T|/Δ is a constant value equal to the exponent of the determined calibration curve. Thus, both 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb CPs feature in the 293-393 K region large Sr values of 2.37% K-1 and 2.71% K-1, respectively. To the best of our knowledge, those values of S r are among the highest determined for UV-excitable Eu, Tb-codoped ratiometric thermometers operating within the physiological region.

elements.content: (a, b) Plots of one-photon (black squares) and three-photon thermometric parameters (red circles) in the function of temperature. Monoexponential functions led through these points are phenomenological relationships and serve as calibration curves only. (c) Log–log plots of integral intensity of 5D4 → 7F5 (Tb3+) and 5D0 → 7F2 (Eu3+) transitions in the function of applied laser power for 1Eu23Tb. (d) CIE chromaticity diagram of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb upon three-photon excitation at 800 nm at room temperature. With arrows are denoted points in the vicinity of the physiological temperature region. (e, f) Stability plots of thermometric parameter drawn in the function of irradiation time for 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a, b) Plots of one-photon (black squares) and three-photon thermometric parameters (red circles) in the function of temperature. Monoexponential functions led through these points are phenomenological relationships and serve as calibration curves only. (c) Log-log plots of integral intensity of 5D4 → 7F5 (Tb3+) and 5D0 → 7F2 (Eu3+) transitions in the function of applied laser power for 1Eu23Tb. (d) CIE chromaticity diagram of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb upon three-photon excitation at 800 nm at room temperature. With arrows are denoted points in the vicinity of the physiological temperature region. (e, f) Stability plots of thermometric parameter drawn in the function of irradiation time for 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb, respectively.

elements.content: The examination of NLO properties of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb was performed employing 130 fs laser pulses from a regenerative amplifier (Quantronix Integra) operating at 800 nm at the repetition rate of 1 kHz. To infer the mechanism of nonlinear absorption the power-dependence measurements of luminescence intensity were carried out (c and ). As the probability of NLO absorption is a power function of the excitation fluence, the intensity of luminescence also follows a power law, where the number in the exponent is the number of photons engaged into an NLO process. For 1Eu23Tb, the slopes of the log–log dependences of integral intensities of 5D4 → 7F5 (Tb3+) and 5D0 → 7F2 (Eu3+) transitions in function of the excitation power were equal to 3.10 and 3.12, respectively. Therefore, three-photon absorption (3PA) was identified as the underlying process responsible for the observed Tb3+ and Eu3+ emissions excited at 800 nm. The same power dependence of both emissions is a strong advantage of this system, because the spectral profile (and therefore the Δ values) of 800 nm excited luminescence does not change with fluctuating power of excitation source. In the opposite scenario, in which the power dependence of emission components is different, the thermometric calibration would be valid for a precisely known laser fluence only.
elements.clean_text: The examination of NLO properties of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb was performed employing 130 fs laser pulses from a regenerative amplifier (Quantronix Integra) operating at 800 nm at the repetition rate of 1 kHz. To infer the mechanism of nonlinear absorption the power-dependence measurements of luminescence intensity were carried out (c and ). As the probability of NLO absorption is a power function of the excitation fluence, the intensity of luminescence also follows a power law, where the number in the exponent is the number of photons engaged into an NLO process. For 1Eu23Tb, the slopes of the log-log dependences of integral intensities of 5D4 → 7F5 (Tb3+) and 5D0 → 7F2 (Eu3+) transitions in function of the excitation power were equal to 3.10 and 3.12, respectively. Therefore, three-photon absorption (3PA) was identified as the underlying process responsible for the observed Tb3+ and Eu3+ emissions excited at 800 nm. The same power dependence of both emissions is a strong advantage of this system, because the spectral profile (and therefore the Δ values) of 800 nm excited luminescence does not change with fluctuating power of excitation source. In the opposite scenario, in which the power dependence of emission components is different, the thermometric calibration would be valid for a precisely known laser fluence only.

elements.content: Having established that 3PA is the mechanism of nonlinear absorption at 800 nm, we examined thermometric properties of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb at that wavelength. 3PA-induced emission spectra taken in the 294–393 K range experience temperature-dependent changes that are similar to those observed for one-photon thermometric experiments (). The evolution of luminescence color upon three-photon excitation is depicted in Commission Internationale de l’Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity diagrams (d), highlighting high color contrast in the physiological temperature region. This is especially the case with 2Eu22Tb whose emission color changes from green through yellow to orange upon heating in a narrow range (294 K to 332 K). In numbers, spectral changes upon heating are also reflected in very high Sr values of 2.44% K–1 and 2.91% K–1, for 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb CPs, respectively (a,b). Uncertainty of temperature determination (δT), calculated as δT = 1/S r(δΔ/Δ), at 298 K is equal to 0.9 K and 0.5 K for 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Having established that 3PA is the mechanism of nonlinear absorption at 800 nm, we examined thermometric properties of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb at that wavelength. 3PA-induced emission spectra taken in the 294-393 K range experience temperature-dependent changes that are similar to those observed for one-photon thermometric experiments (). The evolution of luminescence color upon three-photon excitation is depicted in Commission Internationale de l'Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity diagrams (d), highlighting high color contrast in the physiological temperature region. This is especially the case with 2Eu22Tb whose emission color changes from green through yellow to orange upon heating in a narrow range (294 K to 332 K). In numbers, spectral changes upon heating are also reflected in very high Sr values of 2.44% K-1 and 2.91% K-1, for 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb CPs, respectively (a,b). Uncertainty of temperature determination (δT), calculated as δT = 1/S r(δΔ/Δ), at 298 K is equal to 0.9 K and 0.5 K for 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb, respectively.

elements.content: Nevertheless, the comparison of three-photon and one-photon thermometric parameters reveals that the three-photon ones are always slightly lower across the investigated temperature range (a,b). Clearly, the calibration curve from the one-photon experiment cannot be directly applied to the 3PA-induced luminescence data, because it would lead to an overestimation of temperature readout by ca. 5 K at room temperature and even as high as 9 K near 370 K. This difference is intriguing, given that the same instruments were employed for spectra registration and temperature control for the linear and the nonlinear optical variant of the thermometric experiment. This might suggest that the mode of excitation may influence the thermometric properties of CPs. To obtain a better grasp of the differences in one-photon and 3PA-induced temperature dependencies of luminescence spectra, we examined several possible hypotheses.
elements.clean_text: Nevertheless, the comparison of three-photon and one-photon thermometric parameters reveals that the three-photon ones are always slightly lower across the investigated temperature range (a,b). Clearly, the calibration curve from the one-photon experiment cannot be directly applied to the 3PA-induced luminescence data, because it would lead to an overestimation of temperature readout by ca. 5 K at room temperature and even as high as 9 K near 370 K. This difference is intriguing, given that the same instruments were employed for spectra registration and temperature control for the linear and the nonlinear optical variant of the thermometric experiment. This might suggest that the mode of excitation may influence the thermometric properties of CPs. To obtain a better grasp of the differences in one-photon and 3PA-induced temperature dependencies of luminescence spectra, we examined several possible hypotheses.

elements.content: The local heating of the sample, which might be a side effect of exposure to the high-power femtosecond laser pulses, was considered as the first hypothesis. To verify whether this factor could be operative here, we conducted an experiment in which 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb were irradiated at room temperature with laser power beam ∼500 mW at 800 nm wavelength. The produced luminescence was captured in 10 s long collection windows for 20 min. It turns out that, indeed, the thermometric parameters decrease slightly in the first minutes of irradiation and then reach a plateau that extends to the end of measurement, but the estimated temperature increase, is equal to only 1.1 and 0.6 K for 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb, respectively (e, f). These numbers are far below the 5K difference between the three-photon and one-photon calibration curves. Therefore, the heating of samples by laser radiation, although present, does not sufficiently account for the elevated temperature readout during 3PA excitation, when compared to the 1PA case. Another outcome of this measurement is that the increase of local temperature within first minutes of irradiation is comparable to the precision of temperature determination, which can be estimated from the scatter of points at the plateau. For this reason, the routine temperature determination, which can be completed in several seconds, does not need to be corrected for laser-induced heating of the sample.
elements.clean_text: The local heating of the sample, which might be a side effect of exposure to the high-power femtosecond laser pulses, was considered as the first hypothesis. To verify whether this factor could be operative here, we conducted an experiment in which 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb were irradiated at room temperature with laser power beam ~500 mW at 800 nm wavelength. The produced luminescence was captured in 10 s long collection windows for 20 min. It turns out that, indeed, the thermometric parameters decrease slightly in the first minutes of irradiation and then reach a plateau that extends to the end of measurement, but the estimated temperature increase, is equal to only 1.1 and 0.6 K for 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb, respectively (e, f). These numbers are far below the 5K difference between the three-photon and one-photon calibration curves. Therefore, the heating of samples by laser radiation, although present, does not sufficiently account for the elevated temperature readout during 3PA excitation, when compared to the 1PA case. Another outcome of this measurement is that the increase of local temperature within first minutes of irradiation is comparable to the precision of temperature determination, which can be estimated from the scatter of points at the plateau. For this reason, the routine temperature determination, which can be completed in several seconds, does not need to be corrected for laser-induced heating of the sample.

elements.content: Systematically lower thermometric parameters for 3PA-induced excitation than for one-photon excitation suggest that there exists a mechanism that favors the emission of Eu3+ over that of Tb3+ under NLO excitation. Hypothetically, this might be due to direct two-photon pumping of Eu3+ f–f transitions near 400 nm (e.g., 7F0 → 5L6 at 396 nm, see ) but that scenario is ruled out by the discussed above power-dependence measurements which proved a pure three-photon origin of the Eu3+ emission. Only values of slope lower than 3 in the log–log plots would be indicative of mixed two- and three-photon process, thus any significant contribution from two-photon absorption of f–f Eu3+ transitions is unlikely.
elements.clean_text: Systematically lower thermometric parameters for 3PA-induced excitation than for one-photon excitation suggest that there exists a mechanism that favors the emission of Eu3+ over that of Tb3+ under NLO excitation. Hypothetically, this might be due to direct two-photon pumping of Eu3+ f-f transitions near 400 nm (e.g., 7F0 → 5L6 at 396 nm, see ) but that scenario is ruled out by the discussed above power-dependence measurements which proved a pure three-photon origin of the Eu3+ emission. Only values of slope lower than 3 in the log-log plots would be indicative of mixed two- and three-photon process, thus any significant contribution from two-photon absorption of f-f Eu3+ transitions is unlikely.

elements.content: Another factor to be considered is the possibility that the 3PA populate the levels of sensitizing ligands (1,3,5-btc and phen) to a different degree than single-photon interactions. Although from the point of view of symmetry the selection rules for 3PA are the same as for 1PA, the relative cross-sections for various levels may be different for those two modes of excitations. If the phen and 1,3,5-btc ligands additionally differ in their sensitizing properties of Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions, the origin of excitation may influence the intensity ratio of their emission, and consequently, the Δ value. From the analysis of energy levels it can be inferred to what extent the sensitizing properties of 1,3,5-btc and phen are different. The lowest triplet state energies of phen and 1,3,5-btc are 22 075 and 23 200 cm–1, respectively, as derived from the phosphorescence spectra of corresponding Gd3+ complexes. Well-established empirical rules state that the energy transfer between ligand and lanthanide ion is greatly facilitated when the energy gap between the ligand’s triplet state and lanthanide emitting level is bigger than 2000 cm–1. In line with this, the 5D0 level of Eu3+ (17 300 cm–1) is expected to accept energy from triplet states of both, phen and 1,3,5-btc, while the 5D4 level (20 500 cm–1) of Tb3+ ion should be fed from 1,3,5-btc, but not phen. This implies that the relative intensity of Eu3+ ion emission will increase, in comparison to one-photon excitation, if under three-photon conditions, the excited states of phen are preferentially populated over those of 1,3,5-btc. Indeed, this mechanism can be operative here, provided that the 3PA cross-section for phen is much larger than that of 1,3,5-btc at the investigated wavelength (800 nm). The 3PA spectra are not known for 1,3,5-btc and phen to the best of our knowledge, but one notes that comparatively larger three-photon response of phen is strongly anticipated as it has polarizable fused-ring π-electron system, in contrast to 1,3,5-btc. At present, we take the above mechanism as a tentative explanation that accounts for the noted differences in one-photon and 3PA-induced emission spectra of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb, yet further experimental confirmation will be sought.

Although from the point of view of symmetry the selection rules for 3PA are the same as for 1PA, the relative cross-sections for various levels may be different for those two modes of excitations. If the phen and 1,3,5-btc ligands additionally differ in their sensitizing properties of Eu3+ and Tb3+ ions, the origin of excitation may influence the intensity ratio of their emission, and consequently, the Δ value. From the analysis of energy levels it can be inferred to what extent the sensitizing properties of 1,3,5-btc and phen are different. The lowest triplet state energies of phen and 1,3,5-btc are 22075 and 23200 cm-1, respectively, as derived from the phosphorescence spectra of corresponding Gd3+ complexes. Well-established empirical rules state that the energy transfer between ligand and lanthanide ion is greatly facilitated when the energy gap between the ligand's triplet state and lanthanide emitting level is bigger than 2000 cm-1. In line with this, the 5D0 level of Eu3+ (17300 cm-1) is expected to accept energy from triplet states of both, phen and 1,3,5-btc, while the 5D4 level (20500 cm-1) of Tb3+ ion should be fed from 1,3,5-btc, but not phen. This implies that the relative intensity of Eu3+ ion emission will increase, in comparison to one-photon excitation, if under three-photon conditions, the excited states of phen are preferentially populated over those of 1,3,5-btc. Indeed, this mechanism can be operative here, provided that the 3PA cross-section for phen is much larger than that of 1,3,5-btc at the investigated wavelength (800 nm). The 3PA spectra are not known for 1,3,5-btc and phen to the best of our knowledge, but one notes that comparatively larger three-photon response of phen is strongly anticipated as it has polarizable fused-ring π-electron system, in contrast to 1,3,5-btc. At present, we take the above mechanism as a tentative explanation that accounts for the noted differences in one-photon and 3PA-induced emission spectra of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb, yet further experimental confirmation will be sought.

elements.content: The application of high-intensity laser excitation for MPA thermometry raises questions pertaining to the optical stability of CP thermometers. At constant temperature the 3PA-induced emission of the investigated compounds is stable for relatively long irradiation time (20 min), as can be inferred from results shown in e,f. To verify the performance at dynamic temperature conditions, we conducted the temperature cycling (293 K to 333 K) experiment. We found that Δ values remain stable for at least 4 cycles at investigated temperatures (), provided that the CP sample is not exposed to air.
elements.clean_text: The application of high-intensity laser excitation for MPA thermometry raises questions pertaining to the optical stability of CP thermometers. At constant temperature the 3PA-induced emission of the investigated compounds is stable for relatively long irradiation time (20 min), as can be inferred from results shown in e,f. To verify the performance at dynamic temperature conditions, we conducted the temperature cycling (293 K to 333 K) experiment. We found that Δ values remain stable for at least 4 cycles at investigated temperatures (), provided that the CP sample is not exposed to air.

elements.content: It is imperative to note that the ligands building up 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb are by no means optimized for NLO absorption. Despite that fact we have been able to achieve quite strong and reproducible 3PA-induced luminescent thermometric responses. This is a very promising result, since it follows that modifications of ligands that are to be used in the future, e.g., through the extension of π-electron skeleton, may lead to large enhancements of the nonlinear response and therefore, to the improvement of thermometric characteristics (luminescence intensity, lowering of threshold of laser fluence).
elements.clean_text: It is imperative to note that the ligands building up 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb are by no means optimized for NLO absorption. Despite that fact we have been able to achieve quite strong and reproducible 3PA-induced luminescent thermometric responses. This is a very promising result, since it follows that modifications of ligands that are to be used in the future, e.g., through the extension of π-electron skeleton, may lead to large enhancements of the nonlinear response and therefore, to the improvement of thermometric characteristics (luminescence intensity, lowering of threshold of laser fluence).

elements.content: In conclusion, we presented a new strategy that opens up NIR-to-VIS noncontact ratiometric luminescent temperature sensing in CPs that normally operate as UV-to-VIS thermometers. It relies on the excitation of temperature-dependent luminescence through a 3PA mechanism in the NIR region (800 nm). The relative sensitivities of three-photon NIR-to-VIS thermometers 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb are as high as 2.44% K–1 and 2.91% K–1, respectively. Among the challenges connected with the use of NLO excitation for CP-based optical thermometry one notes that the nature of 3PA excitation itself may lead to the 3PA-induced thermometric luminescent responses that are not identical to UV-induced ones, which necessitates independent determination of the temperature calibration curves. However, we anticipate that MPA-based NIR-to-VIS thermometry strategy should be feasible in most UV-to-VIS CP-based thermometers and ultimately, that nonlinear photon absorption may be used for all-NIR temperature sensing, e.g., in neodymium-bearing CPs.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we presented a new strategy that opens up NIR-to-VIS noncontact ratiometric luminescent temperature sensing in CPs that normally operate as UV-to-VIS thermometers. It relies on the excitation of temperature-dependent luminescence through a 3PA mechanism in the NIR region (800 nm). The relative sensitivities of three-photon NIR-to-VIS thermometers 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb are as high as 2.44% K-1 and 2.91% K-1, respectively. Among the challenges connected with the use of NLO excitation for CP-based optical thermometry one notes that the nature of 3PA excitation itself may lead to the 3PA-induced thermometric luminescent responses that are not identical to UV-induced ones, which necessitates independent determination of the temperature calibration curves. However, we anticipate that MPA-based NIR-to-VIS thermometry strategy should be feasible in most UV-to-VIS CP-based thermometers and ultimately, that nonlinear photon absorption may be used for all-NIR temperature sensing, e.g., in neodymium-bearing CPs.

Instrumentation, synthesis and characterization of 100Gd, 1Eu23Tb, and 2Eu22Tb materials, description of three-photon and one-photon thermometric measurements, structural refinement and crystal data, experimental powder X-ray diffraction patterns, infrared and Raman spectra, thermal gravimetric and differential thermal analysis curves, temperature-resolved luminescence decay curves, emission spectra obtained under one-photon and three-photon excitations, one-photon excitation spectra, emission spectra measured in the function of the applied laser power, temperature cycling experiment (PDF)

X-ray data of 100Gd structure (CIF)

Note that relative uncertainity of determination of thermometric parameter (δΔ/Δ) is calculated from the scatter of points in stability plots (e, f).

By contrast, preliminary open-air experiments shown poor repeatability of thermometric response suggesting that some oxygen-related radical processes may deteriorate the performance of CP.

cln_elements.content: Room-temperature quantum yield (QY) measurements of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb microcrystalline powders (λexc = 330 nm) gave values of 17.3% and 10.5%, respectively. Lower QY of 2Eu22Tb vs 1Eu23Tb suggests that, in these systems, Eu3+ centers dissipate energy to a larger extent through nonradiative channels than Tb3+ ones, hence low Eu3+ concentrations are preferred for maximized emission brightness.
cln_elements.clean_text: Room-temperature quantum yield (QY) measurements of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb microcrystalline powders (λexc = 330 nm) gave values of 17.3% and 10.5%, respectively. Lower QY of 2Eu22Tb vs 1Eu23Tb suggests that, in these systems, Eu3+ centers dissipate energy to a larger extent through nonradiative channels than Tb3+ ones, hence low Eu3+ concentrations are preferred for maximized emission brightness.

cln_elements.content: (a) Energy levels diagram highlighting the use of MPA excitation (specifically 3PA) for effecting the thermometric luminescent response of Eu,Tb-codoped CP. (b) Left: distorted six-nodal rings comprising three metal centers and three 1,3,5-btc ligands; Right: honeycomb-like metal–organic layer parallel to the ab plane. (c) Emission spectra of 1Eu23Tb obtained under one-photon conditions (λexc = 337 nm) measured in the 294–373 K range. (d) Plots of integral intensities of 5D0 → 7F2 of Eu3+ (red dots) and 5D4 → 7F5 of Tb3+ (black dots) f–f electronic transitions in the function of temperature. Insets contain photographs of luminescence colors at three temperatures (299, 336, and 373 K).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Energy levels diagram highlighting the use of MPA excitation (specifically 3PA) for effecting the thermometric luminescent response of Eu,Tb-codoped CP. (b) Left: distorted six-nodal rings comprising three metal centers and three 1,3,5-btc ligands; Right: honeycomb-like metal-organic layer parallel to the ab plane. (c) Emission spectra of 1Eu23Tb obtained under one-photon conditions (λexc = 337 nm) measured in the 294-373 K range. (d) Plots of integral intensities of 5D0 → 7F2 of Eu3+ (red dots) and 5D4 → 7F5 of Tb3+ (black dots) f-f electronic transitions in the function of temperature. Insets contain photographs of luminescence colors at three temperatures (299, 336, and 373 K).

cln_elements.content: (a, b) Plots of one-photon (black squares) and three-photon thermometric parameters (red circles) in the function of temperature. Monoexponential functions led through these points are phenomenological relationships and serve as calibration curves only. (c) Log–log plots of integral intensity of 5D4 → 7F5 (Tb3+) and 5D0 → 7F2 (Eu3+) transitions in the function of applied laser power for 1Eu23Tb. (d) CIE chromaticity diagram of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb upon three-photon excitation at 800 nm at room temperature. With arrows are denoted points in the vicinity of the physiological temperature region. (e, f) Stability plots of thermometric parameter drawn in the function of irradiation time for 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a, b) Plots of one-photon (black squares) and three-photon thermometric parameters (red circles) in the function of temperature. Monoexponential functions led through these points are phenomenological relationships and serve as calibration curves only. (c) Log-log plots of integral intensity of 5D4 → 7F5 (Tb3+) and 5D0 → 7F2 (Eu3+) transitions in the function of applied laser power for 1Eu23Tb. (d) CIE chromaticity diagram of 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb upon three-photon excitation at 800 nm at room temperature. With arrows are denoted points in the vicinity of the physiological temperature region. (e, f) Stability plots of thermometric parameter drawn in the function of irradiation time for 1Eu23Tb and 2Eu22Tb, respectively.

metadata.title:
Three-Photon
Absorption of Coordination Polymer Transforms
UV-to-VIS Thermometry into NIR-to-VIS Thermometry
